_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Thatcher Company of Nevada, Inc.- Sparks (TCNV-Sparks)is a leader in the water purification chemical industry manufactures and distributes environmental chemicals for the municipal, agricultural, mining, and industrial markets. TCNV-Sparks is a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors and has been certified to be in compliance with the Responsible Distribution Code. The company is also an active member of the Chlorine Institute, a trade group that develops and establishes recommended practices for the safe handling of chlorine.



The TCNV-Sparks facility is a repackager and distributor of various industrial chemicals. The major markets for the Sparks plant include drinking water treatment, wastewater treatment, industrial applications, agriculture, and food processing. Chlorine from our Stockton, CA packaging facility is distributed through the Sparks facility to the water treatment, wastewater treatment, agriculture and industrial markets. Sulfur dioxide is repackaged at the Sparks facility and distributed to many of the same industrial markets. 



Thatcher Group states in its EHSS Charter that the Environmental, Health, Safety, and Security Mission is to achieve a manufacturing environment that we are proud of by continuously improving our ability to provide our customers with quality products and services that meet their needs while operating with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance. To operate with the highest standards of safety and environmental compliance, our commitment to EHSS must include: compliance with work instructions and procedures; clear expectations; a constant focus on prevention; active participation; awareness on and off the job; strong leadership; and personal responsibility. Further, a commitment to EHSS must include personal accountability for their EHSS performance and for the EHSS performance of those they manage or supervise. A commitment on the part of all employees and contractors is crucial

to achieving the EHSS mission. Compliance with all expectations set forth in the EHSS Charter will help develop the EHSS culture and ensure Carus operates with the highest standards of safely and environmental awareness. These expectations are a key part of job performance assessments. Thatcher Group will not tolerate failure to live up to the expectations outlined in this charter; as such failure could negatively impact the health and safety of our employees, our community, and the environment. In addition to EPA's RMP rule, the Sparks plant complies with State and Federal OSHA's Process Safety Management, EPA's State and Federal Hazardous Waste Generator, DHS's Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard and DOT's Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration regulatory requirements.



In this RMP submission, there is one Worst-case toxic release scenario and one Alternative Case toxic release scenario evaluated at the Sparks plant for each of the two toxic gases; chlorine and sulfur dioxide. Section 2 of this RMP submittal contains additional details regarding the Worst-case release scenario while Section 3 contains additional details for the Alternative Case release scenario. The Hazard Prediction and Analysis Capability (HPAC) model was developed by the U.S. Department of Defense (DOD) through the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA). These HPAC models has been approved by the Chlorine Institute and is published in their Pamphlet 74 Edition 6 and was used to develop the worst-case and alternative scenarios for all chlorine releases and to determine the greatest distances to the chlorine toxic endpoint of 3 ppm.



For chlorine, the Worst-case toxic release scenario has been determined to be the largest container which results in the longest release distance, which is a 1-ton cylinder, known as a tonner, releasing 2,000 pounds with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 0.14 mile. The scenario and conditions are described in Chlorine Institute's Pa

mphlet 74 Edition 6 as:



4.4.2 1-Ton Container

? Total mass release = 2,000 lbs.

? Duration of release = 10 minutes

? Release state = gas

? Release rate: 3.33 lbs./second

? Release occurs on concrete

? Wind Speed = 1.5 m/s @ 3ppm

? Maximum downwind distance = 738 ft. = 0.14 miles

? Maximum width = 988 ft.



An Alternative Case toxic release scenario has been determined to be a more likely release from the next largest container, which is a 150 lb. cylinder, releasing 150 pounds with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 0.1 mile. The scenario and conditions are described in Chlorine Institute's Pamphlet 74 Edition 6 as:



4.4.1 150-lb. Cylinder 

? Total mass release = 150 pounds

? 10 minute release

? 0.25 pounds/second steady state release

? Release occurs on concrete

? Wind Speed = 1.5 m/s @ 3 ppm

? Maximum downwind distance = 210 ft. = 0.04 ~  0.10 miles (minimum distance)

? Maximum width = 386 ft.



For sulfur dioxide, the Worst-case toxic release scenario has been determined to be the largest container which results in the longest release distance, which is a sulfur dioxide railcar releasing 180,000 pounds with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 14.8 miles using EPA's RMP Guidance for Chemical Distributors Reference Tables or Equationsand for the modeling. An Alternative Case toxic release scenario to be a more likely release from the next largest container, which is a 34,000 pound sulfur dioxide cargo tanker, with a maximum distance to a 3 ppm end point of 0.88 mile, again, using EPA's RMP Guidance for Chemical Distributors Reference Tables or Equationsand for the modeling. To ensure a common basis for comparisons, EPA defined the worst-case scenario as the release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line that results in the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint. The alternative release scenario is a release that is considered more reasonable or "more likely." These maximu

m distances are used to determine the radii for circles around the covered processes. Residential populations within these circles are required to be determined based on available census information; hence, the population number for each scenario is reported as part of this RMP submittal. These estimates were acquired from the EPA Marplot software. Since wind direction cannot be anticipated for an accidental release, EPA mandated the circle estimation method. This method greatly over estimates the population potentially exposed to an individual release since the prominent wind direction and other factors are not taken into account. Generally, the Sparks Plant components for the accidental release prevention program includes a commitment to process safety, an understanding of hazards and risk, management of risk and learning from experience as well as compliance with regulatory requirements.



The plant has a Process Safety Management (PSM) system for the covered processes as defined by OSHA. The chlorine and sulfur dioxide program documentation includes the following PSM elements: process safety information; process hazard analysis; operating procedures; training; mechanical integrity; management of change; pre-startup safety review; compliance audits; incident investigations; employee participation; hot work permit; contractor management; and emergency planning and response. Throughout the plant, a hierarchy of controls has been implemented including hazard elimination, substitution, engineering controls, toxic gas sensors, administrative controls and personal protective equipment to minimize or eliminate exposure to hazards. Infrastructure security improvements at designated areas in the plant have been implemented that provide layers of protection against deliberate man-made incidents in accordance with applicable elements of U.S. Department of Homeland Security's CFATS Risk Based Performance Standards.



In the past five years, the Sparks plant has had only on

e accidental release that resulted in a brief shelter-in-place and partial evacuation response for a few neighboring employees; a chlorine release on June 29, 2015 that resulted in 23 pounds of chlorine gas being emitted into the atmosphere from a defective 150-pound cylinder stored in the yard. The cylinder corroded from the inside due to water contamination introduced at a customer site. This allowed a hole to develop in the sidewall of the cylinder and resulted in the release of the remaining liquid and gas in the cylinder. Plant emergency responders quickly patched the defective cylinder to prevent further release, while 911 responders from the Sparks Fire Department assisted in the response. Several employees of neighboring businesses were evacuated and sheltered-in-place by the Sparks Fire Department as a precautionary measure.
